newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria laggs behind few IMF reform targets - c.ban.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria laggs behind few IMF reform targets - c.ban.

text.p: Bulgaria's implementation of the reform plan agreed with the International Monetary Fund last month has fallen behind schedule, central bank governor Lyubomir Filipov said on Thursday.

"We were either more optimistic than the situation called for, or the (stabilisation) measures were not implemented properly," Filipov told reporters after the weekly central bank meeting. "We were too optimistic about restoring confidence in the banking system."

On Wednesday, IMF mission leader Anne McGuirk said the fund was concerned about the general stance of monetary and fiscal policy. She saw the weakening Bulgarian currency as a sign of insufficient financial discipline.
Bulgaria has fulfilled some of financial policy commitments like cutting uncollateralised refinancing by the central bank and reducing blocked interbank settlements, said Filipov.
But inflation is higher than targetted, which indicates that some factors were underestimated.
The cumulative inflation for the first seven months already stands at 82 percent after monthly inflation recorded its highest monthly rise ever of 23.3 percent in July.

The socialist government, battling a financial crisis triggered by slow market reforms, has in July raised utility prices and taxes in a bid to stabilise the state budget in line with pledges made to international lenders.
The government projected annual cumulative inflation at 105 percent, however, the National Statistics Office saw this year's consumer price inflation at around 150 percent.

Bulgaria has pledged to bring monthly inflation down to 2.5 percent by the end of 1996. Closing scores of loss-making state firms and restructuring its ailing banking sector are also essential elements in the reform plan.
